wiki/Patterns.html.title: Overview about typical used patterns | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Patterns.html.keywords: Overview about typical used patterns GOF Pattern Template Method In class libraries with similar sibling classes the Template Method pattern is often seen. It allows to define in the parent class a common overall logic, where the individual steps could be adjusted regarding the needs in the derived classes. In the sample AddDevice is the Template Method which defines three steps. The middle step AddDeviceCore should allow the derived classes to implement its own logic. So this step can be defined as abstract or virtual to allow overriding. public class ParentClass { ... public void AddDevice(IDevice device) { DoSomethingBefore(); AddDeviceCore(device); DoSomethingAfter(); } protected abstract void AddDeviceCore(IDevice device); ... In the subclass now AddDeviceCore needs to be implemented. public class ParentClass { ... protected override void AddDeviceCore(IDevice device) { DecoderType.Value = device.DecoderName; ... } ... One other thing is to remark here. In the typical case, that only one step needs to be adjusted, the overridable method is named like the calling method with the suffic Core .

wiki/DevTree.html.title: Developer Tree (aka Solution Tree) | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/DevTree.html.keywords: Developer Tree (aka Solution Tree) Solution The Solution consists of these projects: DomainModel Contains the (UI-)Domain classes of the Configuration Client ConfigClient.ConsoleApp The runner to instantiate the ExcelAdapter . ConfigClient.ExcelAdapter The ExcelAdapter is the bridge to configure the Config Client via an Excel sheet. ConfigClient.Sdk This project could be treated as an internal SDK for test developers to interact with UI elements (abstracts the UI). ConfigClient.Sdk.Tests Unit tests for ConfigClient.Sdk ConfigClient.Api API for high level interaction with the Config Client to address use cases. The disctinction beween the SDK and the API is the level of abstraction. SDK abstracts the UI, API abstracts an use case. To add a device it is one call in the API ( Add Device ) but it needs different steps of the UI which are triggered via the SDK ( Activate Device Pane , Select the device type in tree , setup the device properties ).

wiki/Architecture.html.title: Architecture Overview | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Architecture.html.keywords: Architecture Overview Main Classes Devices All devices have one common property - that is the name of the device. Depending on the device type a device is listed in the DeviceTree on the left side or a pane on the right side. All devices are derives from IDevice and Device . DeviceManager To add and/or configure a device it is necessary to know how the device needs to be added. Some devices are added by using a context sensitive menu at the device type node in the tree others are added via button in the pane. A DeviceManager is responisible to handle that logic for a specific device. That means, each device needs a corresponding and individual DeviceManager. All these DeviceManagers are subclasses of DeviceManager . AddDeviceDialog During adding a device, most devices need some details specified via a dialog. These dialogs are subclasses of a class generic AddDeviceDialog<T> where T : IDevice . All devices with needs further details captured via a dialog, should derive from AddDeviceDialog<T> and implement the necessary individual logic.

wiki/Good_to_know.html.title: Good to know | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Good_to_know.html.keywords: Good to know XUnit Categories, Trait To group unit test in a way which makes sense for a project, the Attribute Trait is used. The following example puts the test method Can_Start_App under the category UI-Basics . [Theory, Trait("Category", "UI-Basics")] [InlineData(false)] public void Can_Start_App(bool closeAppAfterRun) ReSharper 's Unit Test Explorer ( Extensions > ReSharper > Windows > Unit Tests or Ctrl + Alt + U ) shows the method then under category UI-Basics and belonging class: InlineData and MemberData XUnit allows the definition of multiple input values for a test. Such parametrizable tests needs to have the attribute Theory . Test without parameters are setup as Fact . With InlineData the parameters of the text method are filled with the corresponding data of the InlineData definition: [Theory] [InlineData("1.1.1.1", DecoderType.BarcoMonitorWall)] [InlineData("223.255.255.255", DecoderType.VideoJetDecoder7000)] public void Can_add_and_configure_decoder_device(string deviceName, DecoderType decoderType) With MemberData it is possible to extract the test-data provider for better readability: [Theory] [MemberData(nameof(Data))] public void Can_switch_Panes(PaneTypeWithPaneName paneTypeWithPaneName) { ... public static IEnumerable<object[]> Data => new List<object[]> { new object[] { new PaneTypeWithPaneName(...) }, new object[] { new PaneTypeWithPaneName(...) }, ...

sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.title: Class DeviceManager | BVMS UI Automation
sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.keywords: Class DeviceManager A DeviceManager handles how a device is added, modified and removed in the UI. Depending upon the type of a device some devices appear as own nodes in the DeviceTree and others only as a table in the right pane. Therefore very distinct UI approaches are necessary to access and manage these devices. Inheritance System.Object DeviceManager TreeDeviceManager Inherited Members System.Object.ToString() System.Object.Equals(System.Object) System.Object.Equals(System.Object, System.Object) System.Object.ReferenceEquals(System.Object, System.Object) System.Object.GetHashCode() System.Object.GetType() System.Object.MemberwiseClone() Namespace : Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices Assembly : Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.dll Syntax public abstract class DeviceManager Constructors DeviceManager() Initializes a new instance of the DeviceManager class. Declaration protected DeviceManager() Properties Uri Gets the URI for the node where the DeviceManager is responsible for. Declaration protected abstract string Uri { get; } Property Value Type Description System.String The URI. Methods AddDevice(IDevice) Adds a new device to the DeviceTree. Declaration public virtual void AddDevice(IDevice device) Parameters Type Name Description IDevice device The new device. Remarks It implements the template method pattern. The high level process is always the same - first select the node of the device type and then the add logic is called. Both steps differ inside for the individual device types. AddDeviceCore(AutomationElement, IDevice) Adds an individual device. Declaration protected abstract void AddDeviceCore(AutomationElement node, IDevice device) Parameters Type Name Description AutomationElement node The parent node where the device needs to be added. IDevice device The new device configuration. Remarks It implements the template method pattern. The high level process is always the same - first select the device to configure and then the configuration logic is called. Both steps differ inside for the individual device types. ConfigureDeviceCore(AutomationElement, IDevice) Configures an individual device. Declaration protected abstract void ConfigureDeviceCore(AutomationElement node, IDevice device) Parameters Type Name Description AutomationElement node The node of the device to modify. IDevice device The device to configure. Remarks Needs to get overwritten for individual device types (variable part of the calling template method). RemoveDevice(String) Removes a device. Declaration public virtual void RemoveDevice(string deviceName) Parameters Type Name Description System.String deviceName Name of the device to remove. Remarks It implements the template method pattern. The high level process is always the same - first select the device to remove and then the remove logic is called. Both steps differ inside for the individual device types. RemoveDeviceCore(AutomationElement, String) Removes an individual device. Declaration protected abstract void RemoveDeviceCore(AutomationElement automationElement, string deviceName) Parameters Type Name Description AutomationElement automationElement The automation element. sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.title: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices | BVMS UI Automation
sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.keywords: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices Classes AddDeviceDialog<T> Base class for dialogs which appears during creation of a device. ContextMenuManager Manager to handle context menus. DeviceDialog<T> Base class for all dialogs which are related to devices. DeviceManager A DeviceManager handles how a device is added, modified and removed in the UI. Depending upon the type of a device some devices appear as own nodes in the DeviceTree and others only as a table in the right pane. Therefore very distinct UI approaches are necessary to access and manage these devices. DevicesPageObject Page Object for the DeviceTree and belonging pane at right side. Dialog Base class to interact with dialogs. SimpleDialog Simple Dialog. TreeDeviceManager A TreeDeviceManager handles how devices, which appears as own nodes in the DeviceTree, has to be managed. Usually it covers the calling of context sensitive menus and showing related dialog.
